abstract.para: Voucher status, scientific name, common name, family, provenance, and rarity of the plants found on the Dangermond Preserve

intellectualRights.para: This work is dedicated to the public domain under the Creative Commons Universal 1.0 Public Domain Dedication. To view a copy of this dedication, visit https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/.

taxonomicCoverage.generalTaxonomicCoverage: all vascular plants identified to speices

description.para: From 2012 to 2014, WRA botanists conducted floristic surveys across the entirety of the CJRs; these surveys were aimed at documenting both general plant diversity and the potential presence of special-status plant species. Prior to these surveys, WRA developed a list of special-status plant species documented from the region based on distribution records from the sources listed in above. WRA used those sources, as well as information provided by Baldwin et al. (2012), Hendrickson et al. (1998), and Smith (1998) to determine suitable habitat for each of the specialstatus plants documented from the region. Using this information, WRA botanists identified appropriate habitats to survey for each of the targeted species. These targeted survey areas were modified as needed based on observations of current site conditions. During surveys, WRA botanists walked meandering, intuitive transects through suitable habitat for each of the targeted species. Surveys were floristic in nature, and all observed species were identified to the level necessary to determine rarity. Observations of targeted special-status species, as well as observations of any other rare or unique species, were recorded on field maps or were mapped using a handheld GPS unit with sub-meter accuracy; minimum mapping units

used for special-status plant observations are shown in Table 4. In addition to general special-status surveys, WRA botanists conducted focused surveys for Gaviota tarplant (Deinandra increscens ssp. villosa [Hemizonia increscens ssp. villosa]), one of the major focal species at the CJRs given its status as a Federal Endangered, State Endangered, and CNPS Rank 1B.1 plant. Unlike the majority of special-status plants found at the CJRs which are perennials expected to occur in the same locality year after year, Gaviota tarplant is an annual species and has the potential to experience relatively large shifts in distribution from year to year. The distribution of this species at the CJRs was mapped in 2012, 2013, and 2014. The goal of mapping the extent of this species at the CJRs over multiple years was to document the potential range in which this species could occur at the CJRs in any given year, as well as the variability that could be expected from year to year. CJR - Cojo Jalama Ranches

samplingDescription.para: Nomenclature follows Baldwin et al. (2012) and subsequent updates on the Jepson eFlora (Jepson Flora Project 2017).

otherEntity.entityDescription: Voucher status, scientific name, common name, family, provenance, and rarity of the plants found on the Dangermond Preserve updated after 2025 CCBER Wetland surveys
known plants found on the Dangermond Preserve current as of 2019

attribute.attributeDefinition: A collection effort was conducted in 2019 to voucher plant specimens of the Dangermond Preserve, led by TNC and Cal Poly San Luis Obispo. Plants that were vouchered during the collection effort were documented

codeDefinition.definition: vouchered
unknown

the common name of the species

California Rare Plant Rank CA Rare Plant Rank Description 1A Plants presumed extinct in California and rare/extinct elsewhere 1B.1 Plants rare, threatened, or endangered in California and elsewhere; seriously threatened in California 1B.2 Plants rare, threatened, or endangered in California and elsewhere; fairly threatened in California 1B.3 Plants rare, threatened, or endangered in California and elsewhere; not very threatened in California 2A Plants presumed extirpated in California, but more common elsewhere 2B.1 Plants rare, threatened, or endangered in California, but more common elsewhere; seriously threatened in California 2B.2 Plants rare, threatened, or endangered in California, but more common elsewhere; fairly threatened in California 2B.3 Plants rare, threatened, or endangered in California, but more common elsewhere; not very threatened in California 3.1 Plants about which we need more information; seriously threatened in California 3.2 Plants about which we need more information; fairly threatened in California 3.3 Plants about which we need more information; not very threatened in California 4.1 Plants of limited distribution; seriously threatened in California 4.2 Plants of limited distribution; fairly threatened in California 4.3 Plants of limited distribution; not very threatened in California
and the protection status The “key” is as follows:
FE = Federal Endangered FT = Federal Threatened
SE = State Endangered ST = State Threatened
FP = Fully Protected SC = State Candidate
SSC = California Species of Special Concern
